Texas Personal Injury Lawyers FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions)
--------------------------------------------------------------

**What does a Texas personal injury lawyer do?**

A personal injury attorney advocates for accident victims by collecting evidence, determining liability, interviewing witnesses, and pursuing compensation.

**How do I file a personal injury claim?**

A skilled personal injury lawyer can help you submit a demand against a negligent party for injuries you have suffered due to an accident, and sue for damages, if necessary. They will use their years of expertise and knowledge to prove fault and negotiate a fair settlement for your injuries, [pain and suffering](https://1800lionlaw.com/pain-and-suffering/), and other damages.

**What is the [statute of limitations in Texas](https://1800lionlaw.com/statute-of-limitations/) for personal injury claims?**

In Texas, personal injury victims have two years to file a lawsuit. Failing to file quickly enough can result in the dismissal of the case. A Texas personal injury attorney can help ensure you file everything correctly to avoid losing out on fair compensation.

### How we make money

Bankrate.com is an independent, advertising-supported publisher and comparison service. We are compensated in exchange for placement of sponsored products and services, or by you clicking on certain links posted on our site. Therefore, this compensation may impact how, where and in what order products appear within listing categories, except where prohibited by law for our mortgage, home equity and other home lending products. Other factors, such as our own proprietary website rules and whether a product is offered in your area or at your self-selected credit score range, can also impact how and where products appear on this site. While we strive to provide a wide range of offers, Bankrate does not include information about every financial or credit product or service.

Americans place a high value on car ownership, a fact made evident by the latest car ownership statistics in the U.S. Between 2018 and 2022, personal and commercial vehicle registrations increased by 3.5%, indicating an upward trend in car ownership.
[1] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Most U.S. households (91.7%) had at least one vehicle in 2022 (the latest data available), and 22.1% of households had three or more vehicles.
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)

National Car Ownership Statistics at a Glance
A total of 278,870,463 personal and commercial vehicles were registered to drivers in the U.S. in 2022.
[1] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Trucks are the most popular vehicle type, with 170,239,357 private and commercial truck registrations in 2022, compared to 98,573,935 vehicle registrations for cars.
[1] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
91.7% of households had at least one vehicle in 2022. Only 8.3% of households did not have a vehicle.
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Idaho and Wyoming tied for the highest rate of car ownership nationwide, with 96.2% of households in both states reporting access to at least one vehicle in 2022.
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Only 64.3% of households in the District of Columbia had at least one vehicle in 2022, the lowest percentage nationwide.
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Wyoming residents were most likely to own three or more vehicles (33.6%), followed by residents of Idaho and Utah (32.7%).
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
The Ford F-150 is the best-selling used car nationwide, based on sales in 2023.
Ford F-150 Car Insurance Guide ‚Äì Forbes Advisor (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/vehicles/ford/f-150/)
How Many Cars Are There in the U.S.?
Total number of vehicles
There were a total of 278,870,463 personal and commercial vehicles registered to drivers in the U.S. in 2022.
[1] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
The number of registered vehicles in the United States increased by 3.5% between 2018 and 2022, from 269,417,884 registered vehicles to 278,870,463 registered vehicles, indicating an upward trend in car ownership.
[ (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/#department-of-transportation-federal)

] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/#department-of-transportation-federal)
States with the most vehicles
Montana tops the list of states with the highest number of motor vehicle registrations
per 1,000 licensed drivers
[1] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
in 2022 (2,618.25), followed by:
Wyoming (2,057.22)
South Dakota (1,959.62)
North Dakota (1,949.16)
Iowa (1,594.12)
States with the fewest vehicles
Delaware had the lowest number of motor vehicle registrations
per 1,000 licensed drivers
[1] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
in 2022 (541.45), followed by:
District of Columbia (677.69)
New York (762.36)
New Jersey (917.55)
Arizona (1,030.99)
Increases and decreases in car ownership
Arkansas had the largest increase
in motor vehicle registrations (26.3%) between 2018 and 2022, followed by:
Montana (22%)
North Dakota (21.7%)
Utah (20.6%)
Tennessee (19.4%)
[1] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Delaware had the largest decrease
in motor vehicle registrations between 2018 and 2022, with vehicle registrations dropping by 54.2%, followed by:
New York (-20.6%)
Alaska (-15.1%)
Oklahoma (-9.6%)
Rhode Island (-7.3%)
[1] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Trucks lead vehicle ownership
Trucks are the most popular vehicle type, with 170,239,357 private and commercial vehicle registrations in 2022, compared to 98,573,935 vehicle registrations for cars.
[1] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
How Many Americans Own a Car?
Car ownership in America is on the rise. Only 8.3% of households did not have a vehicle in 2022, a 4.6% decrease from 2018, when 8.7% of households did not have a vehicle.
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Most households (91.7%) had at least one vehicle in 2022, up from 91.3% in 2018.
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
37% of households had two vehicles in 2022, a 0.8% decrease from 2018 (37.3%).
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
22.1% of households had three or more vehicles in 2022, a 5.2% increase from 2018 (21%).
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)

States with the highest rate of car ownership
Idaho and Wyoming tied for the highest rate of car ownership nationwide
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
, with 96.2% of households in each state reporting access to at least one vehicle in 2022, followed by:
Utah (96.1%)
Montana (95.4%)

Rounding out the states with the lowest percentage of households that have at least one vehicle
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
are:
District of Columbia (64.3%)
New York (71%)
Massachusetts (88.1%)
New Jersey (88.7%)
Illinois (89.2%)
States with the most vehicles per household
Wyoming residents were most likely to own three or more vehicles

(33.6%)
, followed by:

Montana (31.1%)
South Dakota (30.2%)

Electric vehicle ownership by state
Sales of electric vehicles (EVs), plug-in hybrid electric vehicles and hybrid electric vehicles accounted for 16.7% of all new vehicles sold in 2023, according to the National Automobile Dealers Association.
California has the highest rate of EV ownership
, with EVs representing 2.5% of total registered vehicles in the state as of 2022.
[3] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Mississippi, North Dakota, South Dakota, West Virginia and Wyoming have the lowest rates of electric vehicle ownership
, with EVs representing 0.1% of total vehicles registered in all five states as of 2022.
[3] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Car Ownership Statistics by Metro Area
Top five metro areas for highest vehicle ownership
The Panama City, Florida, metropolitan area boasts the highest rate of vehicle ownership nationwide
, with 98.1% of households owning at least one vehicle in 2022
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
followed by:
St. George, Utah (97.8% of households)
Logan, Utah (97.7% of households)
Provo-Orem, Utah (97.6% of households)
Gadsden, Alabama (97.5% of households)
Top five metro areas for lowest vehicle ownership
The New York-Newark-Jersey City metropolitan area of New York and New Jersey reported the lowest rate of car ownership
[ (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/#american-community-survey)
2 (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/#american-community-survey)
in 2022, with only 69.5% of households having at least one vehicle, followed by:
Ithaca, New York (81.8% of households)
Trenton-Princeton, New Jersey (87% of households)
Chicago-Naperville-Elgin region of Illinois, Indiana and Wisconsin (87.4% of households)
Boston-Cambridge-Newton region of Massachusetts and New Hampshire (87.5% of households)
Top five metro areas for most vehicles per household
The Idaho Falls, Idaho, metropolitan area was home to the highest percentage of households that have three or more vehicles
[2] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
in 2022, with 38.8% of households, followed by:
Logan, Utah (38.2% of households)
Provo-Orem, Utah (36.7% of households)
Bismarck, North Dakota (36.4% of households)
Greeley, Colorado (36.3% of households)
Most Popular Cars in the U.S.
Most popular used cars
The Ford F-150 is the most popular used car nationwide
, based on 2023 sales. More than three percent of all one-to-five-year-old used car sales were
Ford F-150 (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/vehicles/ford/f-150/)
pickups in 2023.
[4] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Other car models that rank among the most popular in 2023

included:

Ram 1500 (2.1% of sales)

(1.8% of sales)
Most popular car colors
More than a quarter (26.2%) of cars on U.S. roads are white
[4] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
, making it the nation‚Äôs most popular color
, followed by:
Black (21.8%)
Gray (19.2%)

Blue (9.7%)
Grayscale-colored cars (white, black, gray and silver) account for 78.9% of all vehicles on the road.
[4] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
How Much Does It Cost To Own a Car?
In 2023, it cost $12,182 a year, or $1,015 a month
, to own and operate a new car, according to AAA.
[5] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
That‚Äôs up 13.6% from 2022, when the average yearly cost was $10,728 a year, or $894 a month.
[5] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
The AAA attributes this to the increased cost of new cars and consequently financing, among other factors.
Here are some additional car ownership statistics about new cars:
In 2023, the average sales price for a new car was $47,331, and the average sales price for a used car was $29,586.
[6] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Over the past five years, new cars have cost $41,531 on average, and used cars have cost $26,042 on average.
[ (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#national-automobile-dealers-association)
6 (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#national-automobile-dealers-association)
Between 2019 and 2023, new vehicles increased in price by 30%, and used vehicles increased in price by 40.3%.
[6] (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-ownership-statistics/",#sources_section)
Cost of car ownership by state
To determine which states are the most (and least) expensive for car ownership, Forbes Advisor analyzed gas prices, car repair costs,
Average Cost of Car Insurance ‚Äì Forbes Advisor (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/average-cost-of-car-insurance/)
and monthly auto loan payments in all 50 states.
Most expensive states to own a car
California and Nevada tied as the most expensive states to own a car
nationwide, followed by:
Colorado
Florida
Alaska
Seven of the 10 most expensive states for car ownership are located in the Pacific and West, including California, Nevada, Colorado, Alaska, New Mexico, Washington and Wyoming.
Most expensive states for car repairs
Connecticut is the most expensive state for car repairs
($418.37) on average for check engine light-related car repairs followed by:
Colorado ($417.14)
California ($415.66)
Georgia ($407.71)
North Carolina ($402.61)
Most expensive states for full coverage car insurance
New York is the most expensive state
for
What Is Full Coverage Car Insurance? ‚Äì Forbes Advisor (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/what-is-full-coverage-car-insurance/)
($4,769 per year), followed by:
Florida ($4,326 per year)
Louisiana ($3,629 per year)
Pennsylvania ($3,600 per year)
Maryland ($3,349 per year)
Living in these states makes it extra important for car owners to
Compare Car Insurance Quotes ‚Äì Forbes Advisor (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/car-insurance-quotes/)
Least expensive states to own a car
Ohio is the least expensive state to own a car
, followed by:
Iowa
Wisconsin
Maine
New Hampshire
Six of the 10 least expensive states for car ownership are located in the Midwest, including Kansas, Nebraska, Indiana, Wisconsin, Iowa and Ohio.
Iowa and Ohio car ownership costs are reduced by
6 Cheapest Car Insurance Companies ‚Äì Forbes Advisor (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/car-insurance/cheapest-car-insurance/)
, thanks to healthy competition among a multitude of car insurance companies in both states.
Methodology
To determine which states are the most expensive for car ownership, Forbes Advisor examined data for all 50 states across the following metrics:
Cost of regular gasoline (25% of score):
Data for this metric comes from AAA and was collected on Feb. 24, 2023.
Average car repair cost (25% of score):
This metric includes the cost of parts and labor for a check engine light-related car repair. Data comes from CarMD and is from 2021.
Average annual cost of full coverage car insurance (25% of score):
This metric is based on liability coverage of 100/300/100 ($100,000 in bodily injury liability per person, $300,000 per accident, and $100,000 in property damage liability), uninsured motorist coverage, and collision and comprehensive insurance with a $500 deductible. We used 2022 rates from Quadrant Information Services.
Average monthly auto loan payment (25% of score):
Data for this metric comes from Experian and is from 2022.

Consumer Protection, Licensing & Regulation

Pennsylvania Insurance Department
=================================

The Pennsylvania Insurance Department protects and assists consumers, licenses insurance professionals and companies, and regulates the insurance marketplace.

[Consumer Help Center](https://www.insurance.pa.gov/agencies/insurance/consumer-help-center)

[Learn About Us](https://www.insurance.pa.gov/agencies/insurance/about-us)

Popular Programs & Services
---------------------------

* * *

##### View popular insurance related topics.

![Image 5](https://s7d9.scene7.com/is/image/statepa/act146-banner2-100)

###### Help with Health Plan Denials

If you've received a denial of a treatment, medication, or service from your health insurance you may be able to request a review.

[Request a review if your health insurance denied a treatment, medication or service.](https://www.insurance.pa.gov/services/insurance/request-a-review-if-your-health-insurance-denied-a-treatment-medication-or-service)

![Image 6](https://s7d9.scene7.com/is/image/statepa/nsa-banner)

###### Have You Received a Suprise Medical Bill?

If you've received an unexpected medical bill, submit a No Surprises Bill Review Request and a dedicated team will help you resolve the issue.

[Submit a No Surprises Bill Review Request if you've received an unexpected medical bill.](https://www.insurance.pa.gov/agencies/insurance/laws-regulations-notices/no-surprises-act)

![Image 7](https://s7d9.scene7.com/is/image/statepa/parity-banner)

###### We Have Mental Health Parity in PA!

Learn more about your health insurance coverage for mental health services, autism services, and substance use disorder treatment.

[Learn more about health insurance coverage for mental health services, autism services, and substance use disorder treatment.](https://www.insurance.pa.gov/agencies/insurance/laws-regulations-notices/mental-health-parity)

The .gov means it's official.
-----------------------------

Local, state, and federal government websites often end in .gov. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania government websites and email systems use "pennsylvania.gov" or "pa.gov" at the end of the address. Before sharing sensitive or personal information, make sure you're on an official state website.

Pennsylvania Department of Transportation
=========================================

PennDOT supports and manages the Commonwealth's vast transportation network, helping to enhance the quality of life in our communities and keep PA's economy moving.

[Report a State Road Concern (opens in a new tab)](https://customercare.penndot.pa.gov/eCCC/eCCC.nsf)

[Find Driver & Vehicle Services](https://www.penndot.gov/agencies/dmv)

![Image 6: PennDOT employees paving a road](https://s7d9.scene7.com/is/image/statepa/summer%20roadwork%20penndot%20employees%20paving?ts=1726851430874&dpr=off)

Suspicious Text Messages
------------------------

PennDOT is urging anyone who receives a suspicious text message to avoid clicking on any links. PennDOT has recently received reports of scammers trying to impersonate PennDOT or the Department of Motor Vehicles to obtain personal information, such as bank account information. PennDOT does not send texts about traffic violations or fines.

PennDOT is Working for You
--------------------------

At PennDOT, we oversee programs and policies affecting highways, urban and rural public transportation, airports, railroads, ports, and waterways.More than three-quarters of PennDOT's annual budget is invested in Pennsylvania's approximately 122,000 miles of state and local highways and 32,000 state and local bridges. We are directly responsible for nearly 40,000 miles of highway and roughly 25,400 bridges, a system first established in 1911. We also administer the state's 11.8 million vehicle registrations and 10.2 million driver's licenses and IDs, and oversee safety and emission inspection programs.

Whether it's at a maintenance garage or a driver's license center, PennDOT's nearly 12,000 employees are focused on making improvements, enhancing equity in our transportation systems for all people, and striving for a safer, more connected Pennsylvania.

Help after the storm
We explain how to file an insurance claim and protect your home, what to do if you're having problems with a claim, and how to avoid contracting scams. Our Help Line is open weekdays from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. and on weekends from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Central time. Call 800-252-3439.

[Help after a disaster](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/consumer/storms/recoverytips.html "Help after a disaster")

![Image 3: Hurricane prep kit](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/artwork/slider/hurricane-prep.png)

Hurricane season runs through November 30
It‚Äôs time to prepare your home and property, make an evacuation plan, and get emergency supplies. Here‚Äôs what to do before a storm heads your way.

[Prepare for hurricane season](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/tips/protect-home-hurricane.html "Prepare for hurricane season")

Shop smart for auto insurance
What do you need to know when shopping for auto insurance? Use our guide to make sure your auto insurance fits your needs and budget.

[Auto shopping checklist](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/consumer/auto-insurance-shopping-guide.html "How to shop smart for auto insurance")

![Image 5: Home insurance shopping guide](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/artwork/slider/home-guide-slider.png)

How to shop smart for home insurance
What are some questions you should ask when shopping for home insurance? Use our guide to make sure your home insurance fits your needs.

[Home shopping checklist](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/consumer/home-insurance-shopping-guide.html "How to shop smart for home insurance")

![Image 6: Shop smart for health insurance](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/artwork/slider/healthplan-slider.jpg)

Shop smart for health insurance
You have many options for health coverage today. Knowing what questions to ask now can help you avoid big medical bills later. Use our guide to find a health plan you can count on.

[Health shopping checklist](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/consumer/health-insurance-shopping-checklist.html "Health insurance shopping checklist")

To get the best deal on home insurance, shopping is essential.

[Read the release](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/news/2025/tdi02032025.html)

### Insurance legislation enacted during the 89th Legislature

Bulletin summarizes select bills enacted by the 89th Legislature affecting insurance and the people and entities that TDI regulates.[Read Commissioner‚Äôs Bulletin](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/bulletins/2025/b-0012-25.html)

### Insurance fraud investigations recover millions for Texans

In 2024, the Texas Department of Insurance Fraud Unit helped get nearly $58 million in restitution for residents.[Read the release](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/news/2025/tdi03102025.html)

### July flooding disaster guidance

TDI expects insurers and health maintenance organizations to work with their policyholders as they recover from the disaster. [Read Commissioner‚Äôs Bulletin](https://www.tdi.texas.gov/bulletins/2025/b-0007-25.html)
